item.title: (co)fiber sequences
item.description: title: “(co)fiber sequences” Idea Taking the ordinary fiber twice is always trivial, meaning given a morphism $f:X\to Y$, we can take the fiber once to obtain $\text{fib}(f)\to X\to Y$.

item.title: (co)fibrant resolution
item.description: title: “(co)fibrant resolution” Idea As discussed in [model categories and derived functors](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/model categories and derived functors.md)<notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/model categories and derived functors.

item.title: (co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence
item.description: title: “(co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence” For example, we can regard $S^n$ as the colimit $$D^n\sqcup_{S^{n-1}}D^n\cong S^n.$$ Now $D^n\simeq \ast$, but $$\ast\sqcup \ast\not\simeq S^n.

item.title: (co)tangent space (of a variety)
item.description: title: “(co)tangent space (of a variety)” Tangent space Recall the differential of a regular map<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Regular map.md>). Direct definition Given an algebraic set<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.

item.title: 1- Affine geometry I
item.description: title: “1- Affine geometry I”

item.title: 1- Introduction
item.description: title: “1- Introduction” Definition. Let $G$ be a group and $\mathbb{F}$ a field. Let $V$ be a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$.

item.title: 1- Introduction to Finite Fields
item.description: title: “1- Introduction to Finite Fields” Lecture notes Euler function Definition 1.1 ( Euler totient function). Let $a$ and $n$ be positive integers.

item.title: 2- More Finite Fields
item.description: title: “2- More Finite Fields” Lecture Notes Theorem 1.7. Let $p$ be prime, and $f$ be a positive integer.

item.title: A Pedantic Approach to Galois Theory
item.description: title: “A Pedantic Approach to Galois Theory” Definition. Let $\text{ExtF}_k$ denote the category of field extensions over $k$. Its objects are field extensions over $k$, i.

item.title: absolute galois group
item.description: title: “absolute galois group” Idea The absolute Galois group of $F$ can be thought of as the Galois group of the maximal Galois extension of $F$, namely the [separable closure](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/separable closure.

item.title: Absolute value
item.description: title: “Absolute value” Let $K$ be a field. Definition. A map $|\cdot|\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ is called an absolute value when

item.title: Absolute value as action on R
item.description: title: “Absolute value as action on R” Related [Absolute value](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.md>)

item.title: adjoint representation
item.description: title: “adjoint representation” Definition There are two closely related notions that may be mixed up in terminology. By the representation $Ad$ we mean a representation from a lie group<>) to its [lie algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/lie algebra.

item.title: adjoints preserve (co)limits
item.description: title: “adjoints preserve (co)limits” left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits

item.title: Affine coordinate ring
item.description: title: “Affine coordinate ring” Idea It is natural to want to study functions on mathematical objects of interest. In our case, functions are polynomials and the objects are algebraic sets.

item.title: Affine space
item.description: title: “Affine space” Let $K$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $A=K[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. Definition. The affine space of dimension $n$, denoted $\mathbb{A}_K^n$ (or just $\mathbb{A}^n$ if context is clear) is defined to be the set of $n$-tuples of $K$: $$ \mathbb{A}^n={(a_1,\dots,a_n)\mid a_i\in K} $$

item.title: Affine variety
item.description: title: “Affine variety” Definition. A algebraic subset<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md>) $A\subset\mathbb{A}^n$ is called an affine variety if it is irreducible.

item.title: AG dictionary
item.description: title: “AG dictionary” Geometry Algebra Affine algebraic set $X$ f.g. $K$-algebra without nilpotents $A=K[X]$.

item.title: Algebra (over a field)
item.description: title: “Algebra (over a field)” Definition. Let $K$ be a field and let $R$ be a vector space over $K$ equipped with a bilinear product:

item.title: Algebraic extensions
item.description: title: “Algebraic extensions” Idea An algebraic element is the zero of some polynomial. An algebraic extension is an extension in which every element is algebraic.

item.title: Algebraic subset
item.description: title: “Algebraic subset” Affine Let $k$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $A=k[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. For $T\subset A$, and define $$Z(T)={P\in \mathbb{A}^n\mid f(P)=0 \text{ for all } f\in T}.

item.title: Algebraic subsets can be decomposed
item.description: title: “Algebraic subsets can be decomposed” Theorem. If $V\subseteq\mathbb{A}^n$ is an algebraic subset, then $V$ can be reduced into finitely many irreducible components: $$ V=V_1\cup \cdots\cup V_n.

item.title: Algebraic topology and analysis
item.description: title: “Algebraic topology and analysis”

item.title: Algebraically closed field
item.description: title: “Algebraically closed field” Pre-definition. A field $L$ is called algebraically closed if and only if any polynomial in one variable with coefficients in $L$ splits to a product of factors of degree 1.

item.title: Annihilator
item.description: title: “Annihilator” Definition Let $R$ be a ring and $M$ an $R$-module. Definition. The annihilator of a subset $S\subset M$ is the set of elements in $R$ which yield 0 when multiplied by any element in $S$.

item.title: Any Field Hom is Injective
item.description: title: “Any Field Hom is Injective” Theorem. Any field homomorphism is injective.

item.title: Artin-Wedderburn
item.description: title: “Artin-Wedderburn” Statement Let $A$ be a [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md>) over $F$. Then $$A\cong M_n(D),$$ where $D$ is a division $F$-algebra that is unique up to isomorphism.

item.title: Artinian ring
item.description: title: “Artinian ring” Definition Rings Let $A$ be a commutative ring. Definition. $A$ is called Artinian if every ascending chain of ideals stabilizes, i.

item.title: associated p-adic algebra
item.description: title: “associated p-adic algebra” Extending definitions ( trace) We may extend the bilinear form $Tr_{K/k}(ab)$ from $K$ to $V_\mathfrak{p}$ by $\widehat{k_\mathfrak{p}}$-linearity.

item.title: Associated primes
item.description: title: “Associated primes” Definition Let $R$ be a ring and let $M$ be an $R$-module. Definition. A prime $P$ of $R$ is associated to $M$ if $P$ is the [Annihilator](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Annihilator.

item.title: Automorphisms of a category
item.description: title: “Automorphisms of a category” Consider two categories $C$ and $D$. Let $F:C\to D$ be a functor. Proposition. $F$ induces a group homomorphism between the automorphism groups of $C$ and $D$.

item.title: Axiom of Choice
item.description: title: “Axiom of Choice” [Zorn’s lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Zorn’s lemma.md)<notes/ntpy/Theorems/Zorn’s lemma.md>)

item.title: base change, ascent
item.description: title: “base change, ascent” Vector spaces Consider a field extension $L/K$. Given a $K$-vector space $W$, how may we extend this to an $L$-vector space?

item.title: Category of field extensions
item.description: title: “Category of field extensions” The category of fields is poorly behaved. Maybe consider the category of field extensions, as it immediately is seen to have initial (and terminal?

item.title: Cayley-Hamilton theorem
item.description: title: “Cayley-Hamilton theorem” General case Traditionally, endomorphisms (over a vector space, for example) were viewed as matrices. Thus the natural analogy is as follows: given an endomorphism, there exists a polynomial…

item.title: central simple algebra
item.description: title: “central simple algebra” Definition An $F$-algebra $A$ is called central if the center is equal to $F$, i.

item.title: chain complex
item.description: title: “chain complex” Definition A sequence of modules such that $d^2=0$, i.e. the image of the previous map is contained in the kernel of the next map.

item.title: chain homotopy
item.description: title: “chain homotopy” Definition Let $f,g:C_\bullet\to D_\bullet$ be maps between [chain complex](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/chain complex.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Homological algebra/chain complex.md>)es. $f$ and $g$ are homotopic, denoted $f\simeq g$, if there exist maps $h_\bullet$ such that

item.title: Character of a representation
item.description: title: “Character of a representation” Idea Eigenvalues play a very important role in understanding invariant subspaces of a representation, and thus the representations themselves.

item.title: Characteristic of a Field
item.description: title: “Characteristic of a Field” Let $K$ be any field. Consider the ring homomorphism $$ \begin{gathered} \mathbb{Z}\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}{K} \ 1\mapsto 1_K \end{gathered}.

item.title: Characters are an orthonormal basis for class functions
item.description: title: “Characters are an orthonormal basis for class functions” Related [Character of a representation](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Character of a representation.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Character of a representation.

item.title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
item.description: title: “Chinese Remainder Theorem” For ideals Theorem. If $I_1,\ddots,I_k$ are pairwise coprime ideals<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Ideal.md>), then $I_1\cap\cdots\cap I_k=I_1\cdot \dots \cdot I_k$ $\phi:A\to\prod_i A/I_i$ is surjective

item.title: Class 3
item.description: title: “Class 3” [Cayley-Hamilton theorem](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Cayley-Hamilton theorem.md)<notes/ntpy/Theorems/Cayley-Hamilton theorem.md>) [Nakayama’s lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nakayama’s lemma.md)<notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nakayama’s lemma.md>) [Local ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Local ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Local ring.

item.title: Class 4
item.description: title: “Class 4” [AG dictionary](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Algebraic geometry/AG dictionary.md)<notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Algebraic geometry/AG dictionary.md>) Projective sets, regular functions [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.

item.title: Class 4
item.description: title: “Class 4” [Artinian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Artinian ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Artinian ring.md>) Noetherian<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md>) and Artinian modules [Tensor product (of modules)](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Tensor product (of modules).

item.title: Class 5
item.description: title: “Class 5” Projective, quasi-projective algebraic sets if Y is quasi projective, then for all y there is an open affine neighborhood containing y regular maps between quasi projective sets given such a regular map, there exists a covering of the domain such that the map can be written componentwise as homogeneous polynomials.

item.title: Class 5
item.description: title: “Class 5” associated primes and primary decomposition hensel

item.title: Class 6
item.description: title: “Class 6” Image of regular map from projective alg set to quasi proj is closed Rational functions X quasi proj, Y in X open nonempty then K(X) cong K(Y)

item.title: Class 7
item.description: title: “Class 7” $K\supset k=\bar{k}$. Then $K\cong k(X)$ for some $X\iff K$ is fg over $k$. trasendence, basis of transendence dimension

item.title: Class function
item.description: title: “Class function” Definition A class function is one that is invariant under conjugation, i.e., given a group $G$ and a function $f$ with domain $G$, we say that $f$ is a class function if $f(h^{-1}gh)=f(g)$ for all any $g,h\in G$.

item.title: Closeness in p-adic numbers
item.description: title: “Closeness in p-adic numbers” Two p-adic numbers<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/P-adic numbers.md>) are close if they are both divisible by $p^n$ for $n$ large.

item.title: cohomology is dual to homotopy
item.description: title: “cohomology is dual to homotopy” Cohomology of $X$ concerns $\text{Hom}(X,A)$ for different choices of $A$. Homotopy of $X$ concerns $\text{Hom}(B,X)$ for different choices of $B$.

item.title: coordinate ring
item.description: title: “coordinate ring” Definition Let $V$ be an [Algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md>) of $k^n$, $k$ algebraically closed.

item.title: core
item.description: title: “core” Idea The normal core of a subgroup $H\subset G$ is the largest normal subgroup of $G$ contained in $H$.

item.title: Currying
item.description: title: “Currying” Idea When defining functions of multiple variables, we could use the cartesian product. Alternatively, we can define them without product types by using currying.

item.title: dedekind domain
item.description: title: “dedekind domain” Idea Locally, at least away from prime ideals, a Dedekind domain looks like a [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.

item.title: Defining types
item.description: title: “Defining types” To define a type, the following must be specified: Formation: how to form new types of this kind, e.

item.title: Dependent function types
item.description: title: “Dependent function types” Idea Given a type $A:\mathcal{U}$, there is a notion of a family<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Logic/Type theory/Families of types.md>) $B:A\to \mathcal{U}$ which sends elements in $A$ to types.

item.title: derived functors (homological algebra)
item.description: title: “derived functors (homological algebra)” Idea Let us consider $A$-modules. Consider a functor $F$. Then given maps $M_1\to N$ and $M_1\hookrightarrow M_2$, if an extension $M_2\to N$ exists then the extension $F(M_2)\to F(N)$ also exists.

item.title: different
item.description: title: “different” Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>), $k$ its field of fractions and $K/k$ a finite separable extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Dimension of ring
item.description: title: “Dimension of ring” Definition Definition. The dimension of a ring is the maximum length of an ascending chain of prime ideals<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Prime ideal.

item.title: direct limit
item.description: title: “direct limit” Idea A direct limit is a special kind of colimit<>). It’s naming is a consequence of them being defined before categorical formalism, and also for the fact that one can guess what diagram the colimit is over, etc.

item.title: discrete G-set
item.description: title: “discrete G-set” Definition A topological group is say to act (continuously) on a topological space $X$ if the action map $$G\times X\to X$$ is continuous Here $G\times X$ has the product topology.

item.title: discrete valuation ring
item.description: title: “discrete valuation ring” Idea There is a direct analogy to complex analysis. Given a pole, we are often interested in its order.

item.title: discriminant
item.description: title: “discriminant” Dedekind domains Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>) and $k$ its field of fractions, $K$ a finite separable extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Dual object
item.description: title: “Dual object” Let $C$ be a closed monoidal category<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Monoidal category.md>). Definition. The dual of an object $A$ is the internal hom $[A,I]$ where $I$ is the unit object<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Unit object.

item.title: Dual spaces vs. inner product
item.description: title: “Dual spaces vs. inner product” Dual spaces are motivated by the lack of inner product. By constructing them we replace the

item.title: Dual vector space
item.description: title: “Dual vector space” Traditional definition Between vector spaces Let $V$ be a vector space over a field $F$.

item.title: Duality between affine and projective space
item.description: title: “Duality between affine and projective space” Related [Affine space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.md>) [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.

item.title: Eisenstein polynomial
item.description: title: “Eisenstein polynomial” Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a complete [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.

item.title: etale algebras
item.description: title: “etale algebras” Idea Dual to [etale space](notes/ntpy/etale space.md)<notes/ntpy/etale space.md>) of scheme<notes/ntpy/scheme.md>)s. Stable under [base change, ascent](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/base change, ascent.

item.title: etale space
item.description: title: “etale space” Definition Let $B\in\text{Top}$, and $x\in B$. An etale space over $B$ is an object $E\in\text{Top}$ equipped with a map $$p:E\to B$$ such that $p$ is a local homeomorphism.

item.title: Euler totient function
item.description: title: “Euler totient function” Totient function Let $a$ and $n$ be positive integers. Then the Euler totient function $\phi(n)$ is defined as $$ \phi(n)\coloneqq # {a\leq n: \text{gcd}(a,n)=1}, $$ or the number of integers $\leq n$ that are relatively prime to $n$.

item.title: Every polynomial is a characteristic polynomial
item.description: title: “Every polynomial is a characteristic polynomial”

item.title: Exact functor
item.description: title: “Exact functor”

item.title: exponential (lie theory)
item.description: title: “exponential (lie theory)” Idea References https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1140556/reconstructing-lie-group-globally-from-the-exponential-map

item.title: ext functor
item.description: title: “ext functor” Idea $\text{Ext}^1(C,A)$ corresponds to extensions of $B$ modulo an equivalence relation. 0 corresponds to trivial extension.

item.title: ext functor as extension
item.description: title: “ext functor as extension” Definitions Recall that an extension of $C$ by $A$ is an exact sequence of the form $$0\to A\to B\to C\to 0.

item.title: Extension and contraction of a ring
item.description: title: “Extension and contraction of a ring” Definition Let $A$ and $B$ be commutative rings and $f:A\to B$ a ring homomorphism.

item.title: extensions of p-adic absolute values
item.description: title: “extensions of p-adic absolute values” Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>) $\mathfrak{p}\subset\mathcal{O}$ a nonzero prime ideal $k$ its field of fractions $\widehat{k_\mathfrak{p}}$ the completion of $k$ with respect to the absolute value<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.

item.title: Extent to which ideals determine a ring
item.description: title: “Extent to which ideals determine a ring” Do ideals determine a ring? A spectrum? Related [Ideal](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Ideal.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Ideal.

item.title: exterior algebra
item.description: title: “exterior algebra” Idea This construction forms the [exterior powers](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Linear algebra/exterior powers.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Linear algebra/exterior powers.md>) into a graded algebra. Definition The exterior algebra is defined as $$\Lambda^\bullet V=\bigoplus_{k\geq 0}\Lambda^k V$$ We may define the multiplicative operation as follows: $$(e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_r})\wedge(e_{j_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{j_s})=e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_r}\wedge e_{j_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{j_s}.

item.title: exterior powers
item.description: title: “exterior powers” Definition Let $V$ be a vector space of definition $n$ with basis $\langle e_1,\dots,e_n\rangle$. Then $k$th exterior power of $V$, for $k\geq 0$, is \begin{gather}\Lambda^kV=\langle e_{i_1}\wedge\cdots\wedge e_{i_k}\rangle \ 1\leq i_1<\cdots<i_k\leq n\end{gather}

item.title: Families of types
item.description: title: “Families of types” Definition Definition. A family of type $A$ is a function $B:A\to\mathcal{U}$ whose codomain is a universe<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Logic/Type theory/Universes.

item.title: Field Characteristic and Squares
item.description: title: “Field Characteristic and Squares” Theorem. Let $p$ be prime and $f$ a positive integer. Let $K=\mathbb{F}_q$ be a field of characteristic $p$.

item.title: Field extension
item.description: title: “Field extension” Definition Definition. Let $K$ and $L$ be fields. An subfield inclusion $K\hookrightarrow L$ is called a field extension.

item.title: Field extensions behaving like fractions
item.description: title: “Field extensions behaving like fractions” Field extension dimensions behaving like fractions: L:K K:k =L:k Related [Field extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: fields are not algebraic
item.description: title: “fields are not algebraic” Fields do not share nice properties with algebraic categories such as rings and groups because it isn’t one.

item.title: finite dimensional lie algebras correspond to lie groups
item.description: title: “finite dimensional lie algebras correspond to lie groups” This is not true generally.

item.title: Finite fields
item.description: title: “Finite fields” Definition Properties $\mathbb{F}{p^m}\subset\mathbb{F}{p^n}$ iff $m\mid n$. Proofs 1 Every $\sigma\in\sum_{K/k}^{K/k}$ fixes $k$ by definition. Letting $k=\mathbb{F}_p$ and $K=\mathbb{F}_{p^n}$, this means $\sigma$ is a map such that $\alpha^p=\alpha$ for all $\alpha\in\mathbb{F}_p$.

item.title: Finite Fields of Prime Power Order
item.description: title: “Finite Fields of Prime Power Order” Let $p$ be prime, and $f$ be a positive integer. Let $q=p^f$. Let $\Omega$ be an algebraically closed field with characteristic $p$.

item.title: finite morphisms
item.description: title: “finite morphisms” Algebraic sets [Algebraic subset](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md>) Let $X,Y$ be affine sets. Then a regular map $f:X\to Y$ is finite if $K[X]$ is finitely generated as a $f^\ast(K[Y])$-module.

item.title: Finite Mult. Subgroup of Field is Cyclic
item.description: title: “Finite Mult. Subgroup of Field is Cyclic” Statement Let $K$ be a field and $K^\ast$ be its multiplicative group.

item.title: five lemma
item.description: title: “five lemma” Statement In an abelian category<>), given a commutative diagram then if the rows are exact, $m$ and $p$ are isomorphisms, $l$ is epi, $q$ is mono, then $n$ is is an isomorphism.

item.title: flat module
item.description: title: “flat module” Definition A module $M$ is flat over a ring $R$ if $M\otimes_R -$ is an exact functor.

item.title: Ford's Theorem
item.description: title: “Ford’s Theorem” For every $k\geq 2$, there exists a totient number of multiplicity $n$ [Euler totient function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Euler totient function.

item.title: fractional ideal
item.description: title: “fractional ideal” Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be an integral domain<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Integral domain.md>), $k$ its field of fractions. An $\mathcal{O}$-submodule $I\subset k$ is called a fractional ideal iff $I\neq {0}$ and $I^{-1}\neq 0$.

item.title: Frobenius Map
item.description: title: “Frobenius Map” Suppose $K$ is a field of characteristic $p$. The absolute Frobenius map is the map $$ \begin{gathered} \text{Fr}:K\to K \

item.title: Full, faithful functors
item.description: title: “Full, faithful functors” Definition Definition. A functor $F:C\to D$ is called full if for every pair of objects $c,c'\in C$ the induced map $$C[c,c']\to D[F(c),F(c')]$$ is surjective.

item.title: Functor representing unit object
item.description: title: “Functor representing unit object” If your going to take o functor represented by some object, consider the properties of the one represented by the unit object

item.title: Fundamental thm of Galois Theory
item.description: title: “Fundamental thm of Galois Theory” Finite case Suppose $K/k$ is a finite [Galois extension](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Galois extension.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Galois extension.

item.title: Galois connection as adjunction
item.description: title: “Galois connection as adjunction” The [Fundamental thm of Galois Theory](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Fundamental thm of Galois Theory.md)<notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Fundamental thm of Galois Theory.

item.title: Galois descent
item.description: title: “Galois descent” Idea The oppose of ascent, see [base change, ascent](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/base change, ascent.md)<notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/base change, ascent.md>). For vector spaces, it asks: given a field extension $L/K$ and a nonzero $L$-vector space $V$, how can we construct a $K$-vector space $W$ such that the $K$-basis of $W$ naturally extends to a $K$-basis (e.

item.title: Galois extension
item.description: title: “Galois extension” Definition Definition. An algebraic extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Algebraic extensions.md>) $K/k$ is called Galois iff it is separable<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Separable extension.

item.title: Galois group
item.description: title: “Galois group” Properties $G$ is profinite ( profinite group) $G$ is compact

item.title: galois theory and convering spaces
item.description: title: “galois theory and convering spaces” Idea Dictionary: connected coverings -> field extensions general coverings -> etale algebras choice of basepoint -> choice of separable closure Related [Fundamental thm of Galois Theory](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Field Theory/Fundamental thm of Galois Theory.

item.title: generalized cohomology
item.description: title: “generalized cohomology” Idea We wish here to record the axioms of cohomology. In addition, we take the perspective that cohomology is a certain hom-functor (see [cohomology is dual to homotopy](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/cohomology is dual to homotopy.

item.title: Graded ring
item.description: title: “Graded ring” Definition Definition. A graded ring is a ring $S$ together with a decomposition $$S=\bigoplus_{d\geq 0}S_d$$ of $S$ into a direct sum of abelian groups $S_d$ such that $$S_d\cdot S_e\subseteq S_{d+e}\quad\forall d,e\geq 0.

item.title: Grassmanian
item.description: title: “Grassmanian” Definition The Grassmanian $Gr(k,n)$ is, as a set, the collection of $k$-dimensional subspaces of the $n$-dimensional vector space $V$.

item.title: Grothendieck coverage
item.description: title: “Grothendieck coverage” Idea An abstraction of the manner in which open sets cover a topological space. A category with a Grothendieck coverage is a site<notes/ntpy/site.

item.title: Group hom into abelian group
item.description: title: “Group hom into abelian group” Homomorphism into a commutative group extends to homomorphism on domain modulo commutator

item.title: group objects
item.description: title: “group objects” Idea A sense in which an object in some category behaves as though it has a group structure.

item.title: Hahn-Banach theorem
item.description: title: “Hahn-Banach theorem” Statement 1 Let $X$ be an $\mathbb{R}$-linear space, $p$ a real-valued function on $X$ such that

item.title: Hensel's lemma
item.description: title: “Hensel’s lemma” Suppose $f\in\mathbb{Z}_p[t]$. Let $f'$ be its derivative, and $n$ a positive integer. Theorem. Suppose $x\in\mathbb{Z}_p$ is such that $v_p(f'(x))=0$ and $f(x)\equiv 0\mod p^n$.

item.title: Hilbert basis theorem
item.description: title: “Hilbert basis theorem” Statement Theorem. If $R$ is a [Noetherian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md>), then $R[x]$ is a Noetherian ring.

item.title: Ho(C) is badly behaved
item.description: title: “Ho(C) is badly behaved” The homotopy category of an $(\infty,1)$-category is not well behaved in the categorical sense. This is perhaps believable because the homotopy category truncates all higher morphisms.

item.title: Holomorphic function
item.description: title: “Holomorphic function” Let $f$ be a complex valued function of a single variable. On an open set: Definition. A function $f(z)$ is holomorphic on an open set $U$ if it is (complex-)differentiable at every pointin $U$.

item.title: hom and tensor exactness
item.description: title: “hom and tensor exactness” Let us consider $A$-modules. The $\text{Hom}(N,-)$ functor is left exact, and the functor $-\otimes_A N$ is right exact.

item.title: homotopy (co)fibers
item.description: title: “homotopy (co)fibers” Idea It is a rich complexity in homotopy theory that [(co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence](notes/ntpy/Key Ideas/Homotopy theory/(co)limits do not respect homotopy equivalence.

item.title: Homotopy category
item.description: title: “Homotopy category” Relation to sSet In [nerve of category](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/nerve of category.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/nerve of category.md>), we discuss that there is an adjunction

item.title: homotopy category, nerve, and decategorification
item.description: title: “homotopy category, nerve, and decategorification” Introduction We generally understand ordinary categories pretty well. By ordinary, we mean a (potentially small) category which is a collection of objects and morphisms adhering to a set of conditions.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: title: “Ideal” Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unit. Idea Given a subset $S\subset A$, the definition of an ideal is precisely the conditions necessary to make $A/S$ a ring:

item.title: Identity type
item.description: title: “Identity type” Definition We specify the following: Formation rule: given a type $A:\mathcal{U}$ and two elements $a,b: A$ we can form the type $(a=_A b):\mathcal{U}$.

item.title: index of lattice
item.description: title: “index of lattice” Definition Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>). Suppose $M$ and $N$ are two $\mathcal{O}$- lattice.

item.title: infinite galois extensions
item.description: title: “infinite galois extensions” Properties $G$ is always uncountable. $G$ is compact Hausdorff (hence a [profinite group](notes/ntpy/profinite group.md)<notes/ntpy/profinite group.

item.title: inj proj modules
item.description: title: “inj proj modules” Definition All modules will be assumed to be $A$-modules where $A$ is a commutative ring with identity.

item.title: inj proj resolutions
item.description: title: “inj proj resolutions” Definition Given a module $M$, a projective resolution is an exact sequence $$ \dots\to P_{-1}\to P_0\to M\to 0$$ such that the $P_i$ are projective modules ( inj proj modules).

item.title: Integral domain
item.description: title: “Integral domain” Definition. An integral domain is a ring with no zero-divisors.

item.title: Integral element
item.description: title: “Integral element” Let $R$ be a commutative ring. Integral elements Definition. Let $A$ be a subring of $R$. An element $x\in R$ is said to be integral over $A$ if it is the root of a monic polynomial with coefficients in $A$.

item.title: integral extensions
item.description: title: “integral extensions” Idea We wish to generalize the methods of field and Galois theory to (commutative) rings. A central notion in the aforementioned theory is that of algebraic extensions<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Algebraic extensions.

item.title: inverse limit
item.description: title: “inverse limit” Idea Inverse limits are dual to [direct limit](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/direct limit.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/direct limit.md>)s and are special kinds of categorical limits.

item.title: Is every gp representation completely reducible?
item.description: title: “Is every gp representation completely reducible?” [Representation of a group](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.md>)

item.title: Isometries of simplices
item.description: title: “Isometries of simplices” What do actions of isometry on geometric realizations of simplices do to their source in sSet?

item.title: jordan decomposition
item.description: title: “jordan decomposition” Idea Qualitatively, the Jordan decomposition says that any endomorphism $X$ of a complex vector space may be expressed as the sum of a diagonalizable and a nilpotent endomorphism, and moreover these commute and may be expressed as polynomials in $X$: $$ X=X_s+X_n$$

item.title: Judgemental vs. propositional equality
item.description: title: “Judgemental vs. propositional equality” Examples If we define $f(x)=x+x$, then $f(2)=2+2$ judgementally. If we are proving $a=b$, then $a=b$ propositionally.

item.title: Krasner's lemma
item.description: title: “Krasner’s lemma” Statement Suppose $k$ is a field complete with respect to a non-archimedean absolute value $|\cdot|$. This can extended to the algebraic extensions.

item.title: Krull topology
item.description: title: “Krull topology” Idea A special case of the [profinite topology](notes/ntpy/profinite topology.md)<notes/ntpy/profinite topology.md>). Definition Let $K/L$ be Galois, and $G=\text{Gal}(K/L)$.

item.title: Lambda abstraction
item.description: title: “Lambda abstraction” Idea We don’t always need to define a function by name. Definition Suppose we are defining functions from type $A$ to type $B$.

item.title: Lattice
item.description: title: “Lattice” Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}$ is an integral domain, $k$ its field of fractions, and $K/k$ a finite separable extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Legendre Symbol
item.description: title: “Legendre Symbol” Definition. Let $a$ be any residue modulo $p$. The Legendre symbol is $$ \left(\frac{a}{p}\right)\coloneqq a^{(p-1)/2} $$

item.title: lie algebra
item.description: title: “lie algebra” Idea There are two principles that make the study of Lie algebras related to the structure of Lie groups:

item.title: lie algebras encode the group structure
item.description: title: “lie algebras encode the group structure” Lie groups are groups with the structure of a smooth manifold. Intuitively, this means there is a way to “connect” all the local pictures into a global one, and this is precisely what the manifold does.

item.title: linear differential operators
item.description: title: “linear differential operators” Definition Let $A$ be a commutative $\mathbb{C}$-algebra with unit. Let $H(A)$ be the set of $\mathbb{C}$-linear endomorphisms of $A$.

item.title: Local ring
item.description: title: “Local ring” Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. Definition. $R$ is called local if there exists just one maximal ideal<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Maximal ideal.

item.title: Localization as a functor
item.description: title: “Localization as a functor”

item.title: Localization of a ring
item.description: title: “Localization of a ring” Idea The localization of a ring $R$ at $U\subset R$ is a setting in which the elements of $U$ behave like units<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Unit (ring).

item.title: lr adjoints imply lr exactness
item.description: title: “lr adjoints imply lr exactness” If the functor $F$ is left adjoint to $G$, then $F$ is right exact and $G$ is left exact.

item.title: map of modules induces chain map
item.description: title: “map of modules induces chain map” Let $f:M\to N$ be a map of $A$-modules. Given a resolution for $N$ (i.

item.title: Maschke's Theorem
item.description: title: “Maschke’s Theorem” Theorem. (Maschke) Assume that a group $G$ is finite, $\mathbb{F}$ is a field, and $V$ is a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$.

item.title: Maximal ideal
item.description: title: “Maximal ideal” Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unit. Definition. A proper ideal $M\subset A$ is called maximial if any of the following equivalent conditions hold:

item.title: Minimal polynomial
item.description: title: “Minimal polynomial” Definition Suppose $P\in k[T]$ is irreducible of degree $\geq 1$. Then $(P)$ is a maximal ideal in $k[T]$.

item.title: model categories and derived functors
item.description: title: “model categories and derived functors” Idea Consider two model categories, so that there are notions of fibrant and cofibrant objects.

item.title: model category
item.description: title: “model category” Idea To study the homotopy of a category, we wish to pass to a setting which isolates the phenomenon.

item.title: Module
item.description: title: “Module” Definition $M$ is called simple if it does not contain any nontrivial submodule. Dual Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.

item.title: Mono, epimorphisms
item.description: title: “Mono, epimorphisms”

item.title: Monoidal category
item.description: title: “Monoidal category”

item.title: Nakayama's lemma
item.description: title: “Nakayama’s lemma” Corollary. (Nakayama’s lemma). Let $I$ be an ideal contained in the Jacobson radical<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Radical.md>) of a ring $R$, and let $M$ be a finitely generated $R$- module.

item.title: nerve of category
item.description: title: “nerve of category” Idea Relation to homotopy Let $\partial\Delta[n]$ be the boundary or sphere of a simplex. In the nerve, in the case of $\partial\Delta[2]\to C$, this means a triangle It is apparent that there is a 2-cell $fg\Rightarrow h$ iff $h=fg$.

item.title: Nilpotent
item.description: title: “Nilpotent” Let $A$ be a ring. Definition. An element $a\in A$ in nilpotent if there exists $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such that $a^N=0$.

item.title: Noetherian concepts in stable homotopy theory
item.description: title: “Noetherian concepts in stable homotopy theory” Related [Noetherian ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Noetherian ring.md>)

item.title: Noetherian ring
item.description: title: “Noetherian ring” Definition Rings Definition. A Noetherian ring is associative, commutative ring with identity $A$ such that one of the following equivalent conditions hold:

item.title: Normal extensions
item.description: title: “Normal extensions” Idea A normal extension $L/K$ is one that does not live “between” irreducible polynomials— it either contains all of the roots or none of them, similar to the idea of the [Prime Avoidance Lemma](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Prime Avoidance Lemma.

item.title: Nullstellensatz
item.description: title: “Nullstellensatz” Idea For a polynomial $f\in\mathbb{C}[x]$, we can split $f$ into linear factors. If you think about what this really means, it is saying that any finite collection of points, counting multiplicities, uniquely determines a polynomial up to scalar multiplication (e.

item.title: obstruction to division algebras being fields
item.description: title: “obstruction to division algebras being fields” Idea [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md>)

item.title: Ostrowski's theorem
item.description: title: “Ostrowski’s theorem” For a prime $p$, let $v_p(x)$ be the largest $n$ such that $p^n$ that divides $x$.

item.title: over category
item.description: title: “over category” Definition Let $C$ be a category, and $c\in \text{Obj}(C)$. The over category of $C$ with respect to $c$, denoted $C/c$, has objects are arrows in $C$ with target $c$ arrows are arrows in $C$ making the obvious diagram commute.

item.title: P-adic numbers
item.description: title: “P-adic numbers” Define $v_p(x)$ to be the largest power of $p$ that divides $x$. Define $v_p(0)=\infty$. Clearly $$ v_p(xy)=v_p(x)+v_p(y),\quad v_p(x+y)\geq\min{v_p(x),v_p(y)} $$

item.title: Perfect fields
item.description: title: “Perfect fields” A field of characteristic $p$ is perfect if $K^p=K$. Remark. All finite fields are perfect by the [Frobenius Map](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Frobenius Map.

item.title: Plucker quadric
item.description: title: “Plucker quadric” Idea (include from [Grassmanian](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Grassmanian.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Grassmanian.md>)) A net in $Q$ is a linear embedding $\mathbb{P}^2\subset\mathbb{P}^5$ such that $$\mathbb{P}^2\subset Q\subset\mathbb{P}^5.

item.title: Polynomial ring
item.description: title: “Polynomial ring” Properties Prime ideals If $R$ is a [Principal ideal domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Principal ideal domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Principal ideal domain.md>), then the prime ideals of $R[y]$ are of the following form:

item.title: Primary decomposition
item.description: title: “Primary decomposition” Idea

item.title: Prime Avoidance Lemma
item.description: title: “Prime Avoidance Lemma” Theorem. Suppose $p_1,\dots,p_n$ are prime ideals. Take an ideal $I$ such that $I\subset \bigcup_i p_i$. Then $I$ is contained entirely in some prime ideal: $I\subset p_i$ for some $i$.

item.title: Prime ideal
item.description: title: “Prime ideal” Definition Let $A$ be a (commutative) ring. Definition. An ideal $p\subset A$ is called prime if the following equivalent conditions are met:

item.title: primitive element
item.description: title: “primitive element” Dedekind domains Let $\mathcal{O}$ be a [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>), $k$ its field of fractions, $K$ a finite separable extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.

item.title: Principal ideal domain
item.description: title: “Principal ideal domain” Call the ring we are working in $A$. Definition. A principal ideal domain is an integral domain<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Integral domain.

item.title: Product type
item.description: title: “Product type” Idea In set theory, given two small sets $A$ and $B$ we define their Cartesian product $A\times B$ to be the set of elements of the form $(a,b)$ where $a\in A$ and $b\in B$.

item.title: profinite completion
item.description: title: “profinite completion” Idea This construction takes any group and gives us an associated [profinite group](notes/ntpy/profinite group.md)<notes/ntpy/profinite group.md>). The part “completion” in the name perhaps refers to the fact that a group is dense in its profinite completion.

item.title: profinite group
item.description: title: “profinite group” Definition A group $G$ is profinite if it is isomorphic to an [inverse limit](notes/ntpy/inverse limit.md)<notes/ntpy/inverse limit.

item.title: profinite topology
item.description: title: “profinite topology” Definition Let $G$ be a group. The profinite topology on $G$ is the one with base $$\mathcal{B}={\text{cosets of finite index normal subgroups}}$$ A [topological group](notes/ntpy/topological group.

item.title: Projective space
item.description: title: “Projective space” Algebraic sets Recall that a polynomial $F\in k[x_0,\dots,x_n]$ is called homogeneous of degree $d$ if $F(\lambda x_0,\dots,\lambda x_n)=\lambda^d\cdot F(x_0,\dots,x_n)$.

item.title: Projective variety
item.description: title: “Projective variety” Definition Let $k$ be an algeraically closed field. Projective space The projective $n$-space, denoted $\mathbb{P}^n$, is the affine space<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.

item.title: pullback and pushforward of ES
item.description: title: “pullback and pushforward of ES” Pullback Given a short exact sequence $$0\to A\to B\to C\to 0$$ and a map $g:C_1\to C$, we may construct the pullback along this map such that the following diagram commutes: Regarding the SES as an extension $E$, we write $E\circ g$ for the pullback.

item.title: Quadratic reciprocity
item.description: title: “Quadratic reciprocity” Theorem (Quadratic Reciprocity). Let $p$ and $l$ be two distinct primes. Then $$ \left(\frac{p}{l}\right)\left(\frac{l}{p}\right) = (-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\frac{l-1}{2}}. $$

item.title: quadric
item.description: title: “quadric” Properties Let $Q$ be a quadric, $Q\subset\mathbb{P}^N$, $p\in Q$ a smooth point<>), $H\not\ni p$ a hyperplane. Then the projection from $p$ onto $H$ induces an isomorphism $$Q\setminus (Q\cap T_p Q)\cong H\setminus H(H\cap T_p Q).

item.title: quasi-proj varieties locally look like affine varieties
item.description: title: “quasi-proj varieties locally look like affine varieties” [Projective variety](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective variety.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective variety.md>) [Affine variety](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine variety.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine variety.

item.title: quaternion algebra
item.description: title: “quaternion algebra” Definition Properties Let $F$ be a field. ( Wedderburn) Assume the characteristic is not 2.

item.title: Quotient of Ring is Integral Domain iff Prime Ideal
item.description: title: “Quotient of Ring is Integral Domain iff Prime Ideal” Let $R$ be a commutative ring. The quotient $R/I$ is an integral domain if and only if $I$ is a prime ideal.

item.title: Radical
item.description: title: “Radical” Let $A$ be a commutative ring. Definition Radical Definition. The radical of an ideal $I\subset A$, denoted $Rad(I)$, is the set $$ Rad(I)={ a\in A \mid a^N\in I \text{ for some } n\in\mathbb{N} }.

item.title: ramified extensions
item.description: title: “ramified extensions” Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}$ is a complete [discrete valuation ring](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/discrete valuation ring.

item.title: Reducibility of finite dimensional representations
item.description: title: “Reducibility of finite dimensional representations” Every finite dimensional representation is reducible. It is an open question<notes/ntpy/Questions/Is every gp representation completely reducible?

item.title: reflective subcategory
item.description: title: “reflective subcategory” Idea Let $C$ be a category and $U$ a class of morphisms. An object $c\in C$ is called $U$-local if its representable functor $C(-,c)$ is an isomorphism for all $f\in U$.

item.title: Regular map
item.description: title: “Regular map” Definition Let $K$ be an algebraically closed field. In affine space Algebraic set > field Definition. Let $V$ be an algebraic subset<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.

item.title: repreresentations of sl2C
item.description: title: “repreresentations of sl2C” Idea A general approach to determining the representations of a group, particularly a (semisimple) Lie algebra, is

item.title: Representable functor
item.description: title: “Representable functor”

item.title: Representation of a group
item.description: title: “Representation of a group” Definition Traditional definition Definition. Let $G$ be a group and $\mathbb{F}$ a field. Let $V$ be a vector space over $\mathbb{F}$.

item.title: Representations are determined by their character
item.description: title: “Representations are determined by their character” Related [Representation of a group](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Representation Theory/Representation of a group.

item.title: Representations of homotopy category
item.description: title: “Representations of homotopy category” Representations of homotopy category maybe tynctor is to homotopy group and consider representations of it undetermined to determine the group

item.title: representations of s3
item.description: title: “representations of s3” Idea The general idea is the following: Consider the abelian subgroup $A_3\subset S_3$ generated by some 3-cycle $\tau$.

item.title: residue class degree, ramification index
item.description: title: “residue class degree, ramification index” Definition Suppose $\mathcal{O}_1\subset\mathcal{O}_2$ are [dedekind domain](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/dedekind domain.md>)s, $\mathfrak{p}_1\subset\mathcal{O}_1$ and $\mathfrak{p}_2\subset\mathcal{O}_2$ are nonzero prime ideal such that $\mathfrak{p}_2$ lies over<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Prime ideal.

item.title: Riemann Surface
item.description: title: “Riemann Surface” Abstract Riemann Surface In the abstract sense, a Riemann surface is a real, 2-dimensional manifold with a useful notion of analytic functions.

item.title: ring of convergent power series
item.description: title: “ring of convergent power series” Definition Let $\mathbb{C}[[x]]$ denote the ring of formal power series in $\mathbb{C}$. $\mathbb{C}{x}\subset\mathbb{C}[]$ is the subring consisting of those power series $$\sum a_n x^n$$ which converge in some neighbhorhood of zero.

item.title: ring of differential operators on convergent power series
item.description: title: “ring of differential operators on convergent power series” Definition Let $\mathcal{O}n$ be the [ring of convergent power series](notes/ntpy/ring of convergent power series.

item.title: ring of integers
item.description: title: “ring of integers” Operations ( norm) Suppose $I$ is an $\mathcal{O}K$- fractional ideal in $K$. Then its norm is $$N{K/k}(I)\coloneqq(\mathcal{O}K:I)\mathcal{O}$$ Properties $N_{K/k}:\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{O}_K)\to\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{O})$ is a group homomorphism.

item.title: ringed space
item.description: title: “ringed space” Definition A ringed space $(X,\mathcal{O}_X)$ is a topological space $X$ together with a sheaf<notes/ntpy/sheaf.md>) $\mathcal{O}_X$ of (perhaps commutative) rings.

item.title: RS are domain of MV-functions
item.description: title: “RS are domain of MV-functions” Paths connecting multiple values correspond to nontrivial cycles on the abstract RS.

item.title: RS berkeley article
item.description: title: “RS berkeley article” Lecture 1 To deal with MV (complex) functions, make its domain the graph itself (think of $z^2=w$).

item.title: scheme
item.description: title: “scheme” Idea According to [Nullstellensatz](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.md)<notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.md>), there is a one-to-one correspondence… … generalize varieties so that on the left we may take arbitrary commutative rings.

item.title: Schur's Lemma
item.description: title: “Schur’s Lemma” Theorem. (Schur’s Lemma) Assume $T:G\to GL(V)$ is an irreducible complex resentation and $A\in \text{End}(T)$. Then $A=\lambda\text{Id}$ for some $\lambda\in \mathbb{C}$.

item.title: Semisimplicity
item.description: title: “Semisimplicity” The a class of objects possesses the characterisitic of semisimplicity if every object can be decomposed into “simple” pieces.

item.title: separable closure
item.description: title: “separable closure” Idea The separable closure of $F$, denoted $F^\text{sep}$, is the “biggest Galois extension of $F$”. This is the result of two facts:

item.title: Separable extension
item.description: title: “Separable extension” Idea The idea of roots being “separable” in the sense that there are no repeated roots is important because it tells us we are working with a “simple” polynomial that can generate all other polynomials with this set of roots (see [Nullstellensatz](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Ring Theory/Nullstellensatz.

item.title: sheaf
item.description: title: “sheaf” Idea Definition Definition 1 (topological) Let us operate in a topological space $X$. Let $U$ be an open set with an open covering $\mathcal{U}$.

item.title: sheafification
item.description: title: “sheafification” Examples Locally constant sheaf One can show that $\mathbb{C}_X$ is a sheaf on $X$ whose stalk<>)s are all equal to $\mathbb{C}$.

item.title: sieve
item.description: title: “sieve” Definition Let $C$ be a category, $c\in\text{Obj}(C)$. Let $C/c$ be the [over category](notes/ntpy/over category.md)<notes/ntpy/over category.md>). A sieve $S$ is a collection of arrows in $C$ with target $c$ (i.

item.title: simple is weaker than transitive
item.description: title: “simple is weaker than transitive” Idea Related [central simple algebra](notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md)<notes/ntpy/Definitions/central simple algebra.md>)

item.title: Simple objects
item.description: title: “Simple objects” Definition Let us work in a category with a zero object<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Zero object.md>). Definition. A simple object $A$ is one whose only quotient objects<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Subobjects, quotient objects.

item.title: simplicial skeleton
item.description: title: “simplicial skeleton” Relation to homotopy For each $n\in\mathbb{N}$, the unit of the adjunction $$X\to\textbf{cosk}_n(X)$$ induces an isomorphism on all simplicial homotopy groups in degree $<n$.

item.title: site
item.description: title: “site” Idea Consider

item.title: snake lemma
item.description: title: “snake lemma” Statement In an abelian category<>), consider a commutative diagram where the rows are exact sequences and 0 is the [Zero object](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Zero object.

item.title: Solutions to polynomials determine a topology
item.description: title: “Solutions to polynomials determine a topology” The algebraic subsets<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md>) define a topology on affine space<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Affine space.

item.title: split sequence
item.description: title: “split sequence” Definition A sequence $$0\to L\overset{i}{\longrightarrow} M\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}N\to 0$$ is said to split if one of the following holds:

item.title: Splitting field
item.description: title: “Splitting field” Idea Given a polynomial $f\in k[T]$, the splitting field $K$ of $f$ is the extension $K/k$ such that $f$ splits into linear factors into $K$ and is minimal in the sense that $K=k(\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_n)$ is generated by all roots of $f$.

item.title: Stability of semisimple categories?
item.description: title: “Stability of semisimple categories?” If a category is not semi simple, are its higher categories semisimple? I.e, does the property of semisimiplicity stabilize?

item.title: Stabilization
item.description: title: “Stabilization” The phenomena where an infinite process terminates. Examples Nilpotent elements in a ring stabilize under the operation of taking powers [Nilpotent](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Nilpotent.

item.title: Subobjects, quotient objects
item.description: title: “Subobjects, quotient objects” Definition Let $A$ be the object of some category. Definition. A subobject of $A$ is an equivalence class of monomorphisms<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Mono, epimorphisms.

item.title: Subring of Field is Integral Domain
item.description: title: “Subring of Field is Integral Domain” Every subring of a field (containing 1) is an integral domain.

item.title: Tate field
item.description: title: “Tate field” Definition The function $v_p$ extends in a unique way from $\mathbb{Q}_p^\ast$ to $\overline{\mathbb{Q}p^\ast}$ with the formula $$v_p(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{\text{deg }x}v_p(N{\mathbb{Q}_p(x)/\mathbb{Q}_p}(x))$$ with values in $\mathbb{Q}$ and defined (after choice of $1<s\in\mathbb{R})$ a nonarchimedean absolute value<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.

item.title: tensor product (commutative algebra)
item.description: title: “tensor product (commutative algebra)” Of algebras Let $A,B$ be $R$-algebras, and $I,J$ ideals in $A,B$ respectively. Then $$(A/I)\otimes_R (B/J)\cong (A\otimes_R B)/(I\otimes_R 1+1\otimes_R J).

item.title: Tensor product (of modules)
item.description: title: “Tensor product (of modules)” Definition Let $A$ be a commutative ring, and let $M$, $N$, and $K$ be $A$-modules.

item.title: Tensor product of vector spaces
item.description: title: “Tensor product of vector spaces” Finite dimensional case Let $V,U$ be finite dimensonal vector spaces over $K$. Let $Free(V,U)$ be the set of finite linear combinations $$\sum_{i=1}^na_i(x_i,y_i)$$ where $n\in\mathbb{Z}+$, $x_i\in V$, $y_i\in U$, and $a_i\in K$.

item.title: To What Extent does the Euler function determine n?
item.description: title: “To What Extent does the Euler function determine n?” Totient numbers For a definition, see [Euler totient function](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Euler totient function.

item.title: topological base
item.description: title: “topological base” Idea Topological bases allow us, in some cases, to more easily describe a topology. It “generates” the topology, in a sense.

item.title: topological group
item.description: title: “topological group” Idea A group with a topology that interacts nicely with the group operations. Definition A topological group is a group with a topology such that the operations of “multiplication” \begin{gather} G\times G\to G \ (g,h)\mapsto gh \end{gather}

item.title: trace
item.description: title: “trace” The trace determines an isomorphism from a space to its dual: \begin{gather} T:L\to L^\ast \ x\mapsto Tr(x\cdot (-)) \end{gather}

item.title: Tychanoff's theorem
item.description: title: “Tychanoff’s theorem” Statement The infinite product of compact spaces is compact. The truth of this fact is equivalent to the truth of the [Axiom of Choice](notes/ntpy/Theorems/Axiom of Choice.

item.title: Unique factorization domain
item.description: title: “Unique factorization domain” Definition. A ring $R$ is said to be factorial if it can be represented uniquely (up to the multiplication by invertible elements) as a product of irreducible elements (an element is reducible if it can be written as the product of two noninvertible elements).

item.title: Unit (ring)
item.description: title: “Unit (ring)” Let $A$ be a commutative ring with identity. Definition. A unit is an element $x\in A$ such that $xy=1$ for some $y\in A$.

item.title: Unit object
item.description: title: “Unit object” In a monoidal category<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Category theory/Monoidal category.md>), a unit object is the unit of the tensor product, i.

item.title: Unitary operator
item.description: title: “Unitary operator” Definition Let $V$ be an inner product space. Definition. An operator $A\in\text{End}(V)$ is called unitary if $$\langle Ax,Ay\rangle=\langle x,y\rangle,\quad\forall x,y\in V.

item.title: Universes
item.description: title: “Universes” Definition Definition. A universe is a type whose elements are types. Definition. The types in a particular universe are called small types.

item.title: Valuation ring
item.description: title: “Valuation ring” Let $K$ be a field and $|\cdot|:K\to\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ a nonarchimedean absolute value<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Absolute value.md>). Definition. The valuation ring of $K$ consists of all elements with absolute value $\leq 1$: $$ O={x\in K:|x|\leq 1} $$

item.title: Wedderburn
item.description: title: “Wedderburn” Statement Let $F$ be a field. Assume the characteristic is not 2. Then any division $F$-algebra with $F$-dimension 4 is a quaternion algebra.

item.title: Weyl algebra
item.description: title: “Weyl algebra” Definition Let $K$ be a field of characteristic 0. $K=K[x_1,\dots,x_n]$. $\hat{x_i}\in \text{End}_K(K)$ be defined as $\hat{x_i}(f)=x_if$.

item.title: When Product of Cyclic Groups is Cyclic
item.description: title: “When Product of Cyclic Groups is Cyclic” The product group $$ \mathbb{Z}{n_1}\times…\times\mathbb{Z}{n_m} $$ is cyclic if and only if the $n_1,\dots,n_m$ are pairwise relatively prime.

item.title: Zariski topology
item.description: title: “Zariski topology” Definition On affine space Closed sets are the algebraic subsets<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Algebraic subset.md>). On projective space When defined on [Projective space](notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic geometry/Projective space.

item.title: Zariski's lemma
item.description: title: “Zariski’s lemma” Theorem. Let $K\subset L$ be a field extension<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Algebraic Number Theory/Field Theory/Field extension.md>). Suppose $L$ is a finitely generated $K$ algebra<notes/ntpy/Definitions/Ring theory/Algebra (over a field).

item.title: Zero object
item.description: title: “Zero object”

item.title: Zorn's lemma
item.description: title: “Zorn’s lemma” There are several formulations: Suppose a partially ordered set $P$ has the property that every chain in $P$ has an upper bound in $P$.
